awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies fundamental problems on the characterization of positivity in complex geometry. Complex geometry is a branch of geometry that concerns objects defined over the complex number field. The positivity implies the existence of plenty of global objects called holomorphic sections, which play a central role in geometry. The research will develop and bring in techniques from different fields including differential geometry, algebraic geometry, and nonlinear partial differential equations. Some of the answers will shed light on the deep connection between the complex geometric structure and algebraic structure. The proposal will also generate appropriate research problems for graduate students and junior researchers.

Positivity of canonical bundles in complex geometry gives rise to intriguing connections between complex geometry, nonlinear partial differential equations, and algebraic geometry. The PI will undertake three research projects to better understand the positivity of canonical bundles from a differential geometric approach using holomorphic curvature, Kahler-Einstein metrics, and the complex Monge-Ampere equation. A class of fully nonlinear equations generalizing the complex Monge-Ampere equation will be also investigated. The first project will study the positivity of canonical bundles by holomorphic curvature, hyperbolicity, and the Bergman metric. The second project will investigate the asymptotic expansion of the canonical metric on the positive logarithmic canonical bundle. The third project seeks to establish a Liouville-type theorem for some fully-nonlinear equations.

por.por_cntn:
One outcome of the PI's award is his joint work with S. T. Yau. Their joint work has resolved two conjectures posted by R. E. Greene and H. Wu in the late 1970s on the equivalence of the classical invariant metrics---the Bergman metric and the Kobayashi-Royden metric---on certain negatively curved complete Kahler manifolds. These conjectures were motivated by the long standing uniformization conjecture concerning the negatively curved complex geometry. The PI and his collaborator have gone further to established the existence and equivalence of a third classical invariant metric, the Kahler-Einstein metric, on the manifold. Their joint work, published in a leading journal, has provided strong evidence and paved the way for approaching the long standing uniformization conjecture.

The PI has supervised two PhD students, Junqing Qian and Gunhee Cho. Both of them made important progress on the PI's proposed projects. Qian obtained her PhD in 2020, and currently a tenure-track Assistant Professor at Union College. Her thesis derived an explicit complete asymptotic expansion of the Kahler-Einstein metric on the complement of three, four, six, or twelve points in the Riemann sphere, by using the modular forms in number theory. This works settles nontrivial examples in the PI's project. Cho obtained his PhD in 2021, and currently a Visiting Assistant Professor at UC Santa Barbara. Cho has developed the techniques of the PI and Yau to settle the invariant metrics on several nontrivial examples of the negatively curved complete Kahler manifolds. He has gone further to investigate the fourth classical invariant metric, the Caratheodory-Reiffen metric. 

With Lan-Hsuan Huang, the PI has co-organized several events including UConn Geometry Day and UConn Summer School in geometric analysis. The lectures of these events were given by leading experts in geometric analysis, aiming at the general audience of mathematicians.The events were well attended by faculty members, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows at UConn and other universities. Each event had a casual discussion session, the Geometry Cafe, through which the junior researchers interacted with the experts. The organizers strongly encouraged participation from underrepresented groups, by inviting female speakers and contacting female students and students in minority groups to attend. All these activities created equitable and inclusive environment for all participants.
